HL7 Standard.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide, CH Core, is fundamentally based on FHIR R4 and defines profiles and extensions for the Swiss healthcare system. It acknowledges v2 and v3 standards for terminology but doesn't integrate them deeply. CDA is acknowledged for document representation but implemented through FHIR resources. Cross-paradigm integration is limited to terminology.

Geographic Scope.summary: The Implementation Guide explicitly states it is designed for the Swiss healthcare system and the Swiss Electronic Patient Record (EPR). It defines profiles, extensions, and terminologies specific to Switzerland, including Swiss-specific identifiers and eCH standards. Therefore, it is clearly a national guide for Switzerland.

Domain Focus.summary: The CH Core Implementation Guide primarily focuses on establishing a standardized framework for representing and exchanging core patient demographic data, administrative information, and essential clinical concepts within the Swiss healthcare system, particularly in the context of the Swiss Electronic Patient Record (EPR). It heavily emphasizes administrative aspects, patient and provider identity, and the structure of clinical documents. While it touches upon clinical data, medications, and some aspects of workflow, its core purpose revolves around defining the foundational elements for interoperability within the Swiss EPR ecosystem.

Implementers.summary: The CH Core Implementation Guide focuses on establishing a standardized framework for representing and exchanging core patient demographic, administrative, and essential clinical data within the Swiss Electronic Patient Record (EPR) ecosystem. It primarily targets EHR systems and other systems involved in the EPR, with a strong emphasis on document exchange and patient/provider identification using Swiss-specific identifiers. While it touches upon medication management, its scope does not heavily involve clinical decision support, imaging, lab, payer, or research systems. Public health systems might have a minimal role in consuming aggregated data, and PHR systems could potentially leverage the standardized data for patient access.

Users & Stakeholders.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide (CH Core) primarily serves the needs of systems and individuals interacting with the Swiss Electronic Patient Record (EPR). Clinical Care Teams and Healthcare Administrators are the most important users as they will be creating, managing, and using the standardized data. While Patients and Caregivers benefit from the interoperability, their direct interaction with the IG is limited. Payers, Public Health Agencies, Research Organizations, and Government Agencies have a lesser, but still defined role, primarily in utilizing the standardized data for their respective purposes.
